sentences: Todd Harry Rundgren (born June 22, 1948) is an American multi-instrumentalist, singer, songwriter, multimedia artist, sound engineer and record producer who has performed a diverse range of styles as a solo artist and as a member of the band Utopia.

sentences: He is known for his sophisticated and often unorthodox music, his occasionally lavish stage shows, and his later experiments with interactive entertainment.
section: N/A

sentences: He also produced music videos and was an early adopter and promoter of various computer technologies, such as using the Internet as a means of music distribution in the late 1990s.
section: N/A

sentences: A native of Philadelphia, Rundgren began his professional career in the mid 1960s, forming the psychedelic band Nazz in 1967.
section: N/A

sentences: Two years later, he left Nazz to pursue a solo career and immediately scored his first US top 40 hit with "We Gotta Get You a Woman" (1970).
section: N/A

sentences: His best-known songs include "Hello It's Me" and "I Saw the Light" from Something/Anything? (1972), which get frequent air time on classic rock radio stations, and the 1983 single "Bang the Drum All Day", which is featured in many sports arenas, commercials, and movie trailers.
section: N/A

sentences: Although lesser known, "Couldn't I Just Tell You" (1972) was influential to many artists in the power pop genre.
section: N/A

sentences: His 1973 album A Wizard, a True Star remains an influence on later generations of bedroom musicians.
section: N/A

sentences: Rundgren is considered a pioneer in the fields of electronic music, progressive rock, music videos, computer software, and Internet music delivery.
section: N/A

sentences: He organized the first interactive television concert in 1978, designed the first color graphics tablet in 1980, and created the first interactive album, No World Order, in 1994.
section: N/A

sentences: Additionally, he was one of the first acts to be prominent as both an artist and producer.
section: N/A

== Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Early influences and Nazz ==
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Todd Harry Rundgren was born in Philadelphia on June 22, 1948, the son of Ruth (née Fleck; April 29, 1922 – April 6, 2016) and Harry W. Rundgren (1917–1996).
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: His father was of Swedish descent and his mother was of Austrian and German descent.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: He grew up in the bordering town of Upper Darby and taught himself how to play guitar with little help.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: As a child, Rundgren was fascinated by his parents' small record collection, which consisted of show tunes and symphonic pieces, and especially by the operettas of Gilbert and Sullivan.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Later, he grew infatuated with the music of the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Ventures, and the Yardbirds, as well as the Philadelphia soul of Gamble & Huff, the Delfonics, and the O'Jays.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: At the age of 17, he formed his first band, called "Money", with then-best friend and roommate Randy Reed and Reed's younger brother.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: After graduating from Upper Darby High School in 1966, Rundgren moved to Philadelphia and began his career in Woody's Truck Stop, a blues rock group in the style of Paul Butterfield Blues Band.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Rundgren stayed with the band for eight months, and in the process, they became the most popular group in Philadelphia.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: He and bassist Carson Van Osten left before they released the eponymous first album to form the rock band Nazz in 1967.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: By then, Rundgren had lost interest in the blues and wanted to pursue a recording career with original songs in the style of newer records by the Beatles and the Who.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: As a member of the Nazz, he learned his craft as a songwriter and vocal arranger, and was determined to equal the artistry of the Beatles.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: In 1968, after recording four demo discs, the Nazz were signed by Atlantic Records subsidiary Screen Gems Columbia (SGC).
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: They were flown to Los Angeles to produce their first album at ID Sound studio.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Rundgren had no prior production experience and remembered that the producer, Bill Traut, "just whipped through the mixes in a day or two ...
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: So I got it into my head, 'Well, he's gone now, so why don't we just mix it again, more like the way we want it?'
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Our engineer didn't mind if we went and just started diddling around on the board ...
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: It was pretty much trial and error."
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: He took an experimental approach to the recordings, employing techniques such as varispeed and flanging, and despite having no formal training, scored music charts for string and horn arrangements.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Engineer James Lowe, who Rundgren recruited for his involvement with arranger Van Dyke Parks, believed that Rundgren had become the de facto leader of Nazz, and that a producer's credit was wrongfully withheld from him.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: Nazz gained minor recognition with their debut single, July 1968's "Open My Eyes" backed with "Hello It's Me", both songs penned by Rundgren.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: They subsequently released three albums: Nazz (October 1968), Nazz Nazz (April 1969), and Nazz III (1971).
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: In March 1968, New York singer-songwriter Laura Nyro released her second album, Eli and the Thirteenth Confession.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: When Rundgren heard the record, he was struck by "all the major seventh chords and variations on augmented and suspended chords", and it had an immediate impact on his songwriting, especially as he began to compose more on piano.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: and she also had her own very original and very jazz-influenced way of seeing things.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: It was that extra layer that made her influential.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: A lot of those chords she got from other people.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: But beyond the elements of her composition, I always thought it was the way she played her own material that really sold it. ...

sentences: I met her right after Eli and the Thirteenth Confession.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

sentences: I actually had arranged a meeting, just because I was so infatuated with her and I wanted to meet the person who had produced all this music.

sentences: after I met her the first time, she asked me if I wanted to be her band leader.

sentences: The rest of the band struggled to accommodate his changing tastes.
section: == Early influences and Nazz ==

== Production beginnings ==

sentences: Production beginnings ==
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: After departing Nazz, the 21-year-old Rundgren briefly considered working as a computer programmer, and then decided that his calling was as a producer.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: He moved to New York in the summer of 1969 and involved himself with the clubs of Greenwich Village, particularly Steve Paul's Scene, and met a number of Manhattan musicians and fashion designers.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Michael Friedman, formerly the assistant of Nazz manager John Kurland, offered Rundgren a job as staff engineer and producer under Albert Grossman, which Rundgren accepted.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Grossman, known for his management of folk rock acts, had just founded Ampex Records, a joint business venture with the tape company of the same name, and built Bearsville Studios, near Woodstock.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Bearsville soon became its own record imprint.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Grossman promised to Rundgren that he would become the "highest-paid producer in the world", which later came true.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Rundgren said he was initially relegated to "various old folk artists that they had who needed an upgrade: people like Ian & Sylvia, James Cotton, and other artists in Albert's stable."
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Shortly after producing the eponymous 1969 album by Great Speckled Bird, he was promoted as Bearsville's house engineer.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Accompanied by Robbie Robertson and Levon Helm of the Band, he traveled to Canada to record Jesse Winchester's eponymous 1970 debut album.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Immediately afterward, he said, "the Band asked me to engineer their Stage Fright sessions.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: I think Jesse Winchester was a kind of run-through for that, because I was pretty quick to get the sounds and they liked that."
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Released in August 1970, Stage Fright reached number 5 on the Billboard 200, the highest chart showing the Band had to that point.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Rundgren was dubbed Bearsville's "boy wonder".
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: His work for the Band was followed by a second album for Winchester (which was then shelved for two years) and the album Taking Care of Business by the James Cotton Blues Band (1970).
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: This project resulted in Rundgren meeting Cotton's keyboard player Mark "Moogy" Klingman, who in turn introduced Rundgren to keyboard player Ralph Schuckett, both of whom worked extensively with Rundgren over the next few years.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: Rundgren was to produce Janis Joplin's third and ultimately final album, Pearl (1971), but plans fell through, as the two artists could not get along with each other.
section: == Production beginnings ==

sentences: In the aftermath of the September 11 attacks, Rundgren created the score for the film A Face to a Name, directed by Douglas Sloan.
The film depicted numerous photographs of missing New Yorkers that were displayed on Bellevue Hospital's 'wall of prayers' following the attacks.
The film was part of a special screening at the Woodstock Film Festival in 2002.
In late 2005, the Boston-based band The Cars were planning to re-form despite bassist Benjamin Orr's death and lack of interest on the part of former lead singer Ric Ocasek.
Rumors followed that Rundgren had joined Elliot Easton and Greg Hawkes in rehearsals for a possible new Cars lineup.
Initial speculation pointed to The New Cars being fleshed out with Clem Burke of Blondie and Art Alexakis of Everclear.

Eventually the group completed their lineup with former Rundgren bassist Kasim Sulton and studio drummer Prairie Prince of The Tubes, who had played on XTC's Rundgren-produced Skylarking and who has recorded and toured with Rundgren.

In early 2006, the new lineup played a few private shows for industry professionals, played live on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno and made other media appearances before commencing a 2006 summer tour with the re-formed Blondie.
Rundgren referred to the project as "an opportunity ... for me to pay my bills, play to a larger audience, work with musicians I know and like, and ideally have some fun for a year."
The New Cars' first single, "Not Tonight", was released on March 20, 2006.
A live album/greatest hits collection, The New Cars: It's Alive, was released in June 2006.
The album includes classic Cars songs (and two Rundgren hits) recorded live plus three new studio tracks ("Not Tonight", "Warm" and "More").
April 2011 saw the release of Todd Rundgren's Johnson, a collection of Robert Johnson covers, which had been recorded more than a year earlier.

On another 2011 release, scheduled for September 13, a further album of covers entitled (re)Production sees him performing tracks he had previously produced for other acts, including Grand Funk Railroad's "Walk Like a Man" and XTC's "Dear God".
In May 2017, Rundgren released White Knight, which features collaborations with Trent Reznor, Robyn, Daryl Hall, Joe Walsh and Donald Fagen, among others.
In December 2018, Cleopatra Press published his self-penned memoir, The Individualist: Digressions, Dreams, and Dissertations.
The book contains 181 chapters, each one page long, and each consisting of three paragraphs.
He said that "I realized that I have to do this or somebody else will do it.
I’m getting to the point where I could at some point not be able to do it myself, and then someone else would do it and I wouldn’t be happy with the result."
Its coverage ends at Rundgren's 50th birthday in 1998, which was the same time he began writing the book.
Since then, he said, "my life has been a lot more boring ...
I'm not doing as much record production as I used to, so interesting tales that go along with those projects don’t exist anymore."

On October 21, 2019, he stopped by the Library of Congress and signed a braille copy—which was produced for him by a fan and National Library Service for the Blind and Print Disabled patron who is blind.
Rundgren toured in late 2019 with Micky Dolenz, Jason Scheff, Christopher Cross and Joey Molland of Badfinger in celebration of the Beatles' White Album on the "It Was Fifty Years
Ago Today – A Tribute to the Beatles’ White Album".

sentences: His most notorious production was for XTC's 1986 album Skylarking, known for the creative tensions and disagreements that arose during its sessions.

sentences: The album is sometimes regarded as both the pinnacle of Rundgren's production career and of the career of XTC.
section: == Style and recognition == | === As a producer ===

sentences: He commented that, in spite of the turmoil surrounding its making, the record "ultimately ... sounds like we were having a great time doing it.
section: == Style and recognition == | === As a producer ===

sentences: And at times we were having a good time."
section: == Style and recognition == | === As a producer ===

sentences: All three members expressed admiration for the end product.
section: == Style and recognition == | === As a producer ===
== Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===

sentences: The Fool guitar ===
section: == Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===

sentences: During the mid-to-late 1970s, Rundgren regularly played the eye-catching psychedelic Gibson SG (known variously as "Sunny" or "The Fool"), which Eric Clapton had played in Cream.
section: == Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===

sentences: After he had stopped using it ca.
section: == Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===

sentences: 1968, Clapton gave the guitar to George Harrison, who subsequently 'loaned' it to British singer Jackie Lomax.
section: == Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===

sentences: In 1972, after meeting at a recording session, Lomax sold the guitar to Rundgren for $500 with an option to buy it back, which he never took up.
section: == Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===

sentences: Rundgren played it extensively during the early years of Utopia before retiring the instrument for a short time in the mid to late 1970s, which in that time he had the guitar restored having a lacquer finish applied to protect the paint and replaced the tailpiece and bridge to stabilize tuning, bringing the guitar back out on tour during the 1980 Deface the Music tour and using it on and off throughout the 1980s until 1993 when he permanently retired the guitar, eventually auctioning it off in 1999; he now uses a reproduction given to him in 1988 by a Japanese fan.
section: == Style and recognition == | === The Fool guitar ===
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Rundgren began a relationship with model Bebe Buell in 1972.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: During a break in their relationship, Buell had a brief relationship with Steven Tyler, which resulted in an unplanned pregnancy.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Buell gave birth to Liv Tyler on July 1, 1977.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Buell initially claimed that Todd Rundgren was the biological father and named the child Liv Rundgren.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Shortly after Liv's birth, Rundgren and Buell ended their romantic relationship, but Rundgren remained committed to Liv.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: At age eleven, Liv learned that her biological father was Steven Tyler.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: According to Liv Tyler "...Todd basically decided when I was born that I needed a father so he signed my birth certificate.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: He knew that there was a chance that I might not be his, but…" He paid to put her through private school, and she visited him several times a year.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: As of 2012, Tyler maintains a close relationship with Rundgren.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: "I'm so grateful to him, I have so much love for him.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: You know, when he holds me it feels like Daddy.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: And he's very protective and strong.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: "Rundgren had a long-term relationship with Karen Darvin, with whom he had two sons, Rex (born 1980) and Randy (born 1985).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Rex was a minor league baseball player (infielder) for nine seasons.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Darvin had previously been with Bruce Springsteen in a relationship that ended in 1977.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Rundgren married Michele Gray in 1998.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Gray had been a dancer with The Tubes and had performed with Rundgren as a backup singer on the tour for his album Nearly Human which led to a number of appearances on the David Letterman Show as one of The World's Most Dangerous Backup Singers.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Together, they have a son, named Rebop.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In the book A Wizard, a True Star, it is stated that he diagnosed himself with attention-deficit disorder.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Nominated for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's class of 2019.

sentences: Since becoming eligible in 1995, he has often been asked about his absence from the Hall of Fame.
section: == Awards and honors ==

sentences: A 2018 poll conducted by the institution, which is not factored in the final vote, placed Rundgren as the third-most deserving nominee on the ballot.
section: == Awards and honors ==

sentences: In 2016, Rundgren told an interviewer: "It doesn't have the same cachet as a Nobel Peace Prize or some historical foundation.
section: == Awards and honors ==

sentences: If I told you about how they actually determine who gets into the Hall of Fame, you'd think that I was bullshitting you, because I've been told what's involved. ...
section: == Awards and honors ==

sentences: It's just as corrupt as anything else, and that's why I don't care."
